tweet_text: So at the end of the day, the pathway to safety has become both extremely narrow (11 out of 1200) and ‚Äúchallenging.‚Äù And standing across that pathway is the fossil fuel industry‚Äôs continuing and persistent campaign of denial and obstruction.

name: Sheldon Whitehouse
tweet_text: That leaves only 26 out of 1200 scenarios. Scientists put them into three likelihoods: zero were deemed ‚Äúreasonable‚Äù to attain, 11 were put in the ‚Äúchallenging‚Äù category, and the remainder were deemed ‚Äúspeculative‚Äù to achieve.

name: Sheldon Whitehouse
tweet_text: Of those 112, 86 have ‚Äúhigh overshoots‚Äù into high temperature scenarios before reverting back to 1.5 degrees Celsius, which creates dangerous risks during that overshoot of tipping points, collapses and cascades.

name: Sheldon Whitehouse
tweet_text: Of those 230, only 112 were still technically possible to achieve.

name: Sheldon Whitehouse
tweet_text: Of those 1200 outcomes, only 230 get us to safe levels of warming below the generally accepted (but not risk-free) level of 1.5 degrees Celsius.

name: Sheldon Whitehouse
tweet_text: These reforms are long overdue. The cost for all these important changes? $0, according to CBO: ¬†https://t.co/2i8IOCtSFh. The value to the Court?¬†Incalculable.

name: Sheldon Whitehouse
tweet_text: SCERT Act requires parties and amici curiae to disclose gifts, travel, or reimbursements to justices, with full disclosure of amicus funding so the American people can see who‚Äôs lobbying from behind ‚Äúamicus‚Äù masks.

name: Sheldon Whitehouse
tweet_text: SCERT Act requires judges to explain recusal decisions, puts in place independent third-party review to test how well the Court is following rules, and requires recusal standard for justices‚Äô¬†connections to amici curiae (major avenue for lobbying the Court).

name: Sheldon Whitehouse
tweet_text: SCERT Act creates new recusal requirements for SCOTUS for gifts, hospitality, income, or certain reimbursements ‚Äì including lobbying/spending by outside groups to get a justice on the bench (due process problem per Caperton case).

name: Sheldon Whitehouse
tweet_text: If SCOTUS won‚Äôt, Congress must make sure the Court abides by clear ethical and legal guardrails, with a process for determining whether reporting or ethics violations took place.¬†One way?¬†Pass my bill w/ @RepHankJohnson, the Supreme Ct. Ethics, Recusal & Transparency (SCERT) Act.

name: Sheldon Whitehouse
tweet_text: Seems like Thomas should be recusing in multiple matters, but isn‚Äôt. How does the Court assure that recusal requirements are being honored, and the facts related to recusal allow for participation? Mystery.

name: Sheldon Whitehouse
tweet_text: Justices regularly accept lavish gifts, lodging, etc. ‚Äì sometimes involving people with interests before the Court. NYT reports influencers saw FedSoc justices Alito, Thomas, and Scalia as most susceptible; Scalia took literally dozens of trips ‚Äî undisclosed! Why? Mystery.

name: Sheldon Whitehouse
tweet_text: This latest secret judicial lobbying campaign, spanning decades, seems to have¬†culminated in advance knowledge about Alito‚Äôs¬†Hobby Lobby decision (the Dobbs draft was also an Alito decision). What‚Äôs being done within the Court?¬†Mystery.

tweet_text: A Reagan-appointed 1st Cir. judge said it well: it‚Äôs vital ‚Äúthat the electorate can understand who is speaking and, thus,to ‚Äògive proper weight to different speakers and messages‚Äô when deciding how to vote.‚Äù Dark money masks who is speaking.

name: Sheldon Whitehouse
tweet_text: So it‚Äôs painful, and long, and you have to exhaust Republican speakers and table or stop dilatory motions and amendments, but you can get to a simple majority vote ‚Äî eventually.

name: Sheldon Whitehouse
tweet_text: There can be a vote to overrule the call, which is debatable; but when that fails, whatever motion or amendment was ruled dilatory ends.

name: Sheldon Whitehouse
tweet_text: ‚ÄúDilatory‚Äù motions, amendments and other delaying mischief can be ruled out of order by the presiding officer.  It takes a fair amount of nonsense before it becomes clearly dilatory, but it‚Äôs then a simple point of order‚Äîno vote.

name: Sheldon Whitehouse
tweet_text: The motion to table allows the Senate to clear the decks of amendments. Each requires a vote, but is not debatable. Week after week, even through weekends, table the bad amendments.

name: Sheldon Whitehouse
tweet_text: Another is the Senate speak-twice rule. Senators who‚Äôve spoken twice on a question can be ruled out of order if they keep at it. That‚Äôs why real filibusters were long, uninterrupted speeches. Not one and done, but two and done.  (Yup, that‚Äôs 100 speeches by Rs ‚Äî sorry!)

name: Sheldon Whitehouse
tweet_text: One is my DISCLOSE Act being in the bill.  Republicans must vote against it for their dark-money donors, but that kills them with voters. Ditto gerrymandering. Lots of focus on those painful votes for them in the bill will help.

name: Sheldon Whitehouse
tweet_text: Here‚Äôs the deal. Once Senate debate on a measure ends, you can pass the bill with a simple majority vote. So if you‚Äôre willing to outlast the other side, you don‚Äôt need cloture. This could take weeks, as other Voting Rights bills did, but we have a few tools that help.
